comments.commentBody: I don't think Moore played all that well.   Fortunately for him, he drew Lee Westwood as his opponent.   Even so, the match went to the 18th hole.

Stenson played well, and seemed to have things in  perspective. The Sergio/Phil match was pitched about right and their golf was outstanding. There was a lot of grandstanding and the US won. We had the better team. Sullivan was nervous, Fitzpatrick was over matched against Zach Johnson, and Willett was a no show. Meanwhile Ryan Moore had a hot hand and plenty of motivation as a captains pick. Snedecker has a chip on his shoulder from his amateur days vis a vis international competition. And then there is Dustin Johnson, idling along in the ninth spot, which is at least five spots above his realistic world ranking. USA!
Oh come-on, can't NYT readers refrain from always trying to connect the bad  behaviours displayed by simpletons to the U.S. political climate? Give it a rest.

The neo-con invasion of Iraq with the plan to control Iraqi oil fields under the veil of anti-terrorism should be added to the Bush list as the bulk of the oil now goes to China in return for industrial services rendered. There must be a lesson there somewhere.

Joint ventures: GM owns 49% Chine firm 51% after GM brought Shanghai
plant into production; and of course there is a CCP member of the management team as an overseer. These people know what works for both you could say as China's GM is supporting the Detroit corporation these days with massive sales in China.
Perhaps US could try "Joint Venture" too?

But not true, the private sector is producing 40% of the PRC GDP today making it the 3rd largest economy in the world after USA. PRC.
The CCP has been wise enough to turn lose the 'free market' economy with very little oversight but state bank surveillance in some sense.
Hey wsmrer; It's everybody's world. Yes if it was not for AMERICA You may not have been born. So China watch out for AMERICA. we make this world !!

Quite right it called Globalization. “Arguing against globalization is like arguing against the law of gravity.” —KOFI ANNAN, FORMER UN SECRETARY-GENERAL.
The impact on the US has been unkind, but not to Wall Street. Do you think the real estate industry is sad about their sales from the money fleeing China as the exchanged rate fall? When America identifies its real problems (short hand: Inequality and dysfunctional government) it may regain prospective on a changing world. Says a critical American.
They do both if they have not used the trick of many corporations e.g.  Apple of moving offshore (Apple to Ireland) to avoid taxes. Talk to your congress person about bring such revenue Home.

Welcome to the world you live America the percentages below are no doubt higher now. Economist (Krugman included) are calling for massive investment in US economy, though changes in ownership alone may do little to help.

American multinationals have generated 11 percent of the jobs created in the United States since 1990, 19 percent of current private sector jobs, and 25 percent of total private sector wages. Almost half of American exports are created by multinationals, and 90 percent of intermediate goods produced in America are bought by American multinationals. Three-quarters of America’s private sector R& D comes from multinationals. See McKinsey Global Institute, “Growth and Competitiveness in the United States: The Role of Its Multinational Corporations” (June 2010).

The Ryder Cup is specifically between US players and European golfers.  Jason Day & Adam Scott are Australian.  They and any players from Asia will be in the President's Cup where it's US v the Rest of the World (except Europe)
Day and Scott get their shot at the USA in the PRESIDENT'S CUP which is a contest between the USA and the rest of the world not including Europe. ..One  part of the world at a time ...Okay?
Ryder Cup = America vs. EUROPE. Asia participates in the President's Cup competition. Day has a bad back.
No Jason Day, Adam Scott, and a raft of Asian players.  Obviously great golf, Rory, Sergio, Phil, and the newer guys, but somethings missing.

isn't this the way of sports lately. If players want to earn such large sums, the fan base must increase and, in the process, a certain fan involvement that the more traditional fans cringe at. Is this a call to, ahem, "Make Gold Great Again?" I hope not.
Tennis is headed this way, too. Sometimes it's obnoxious, but when sports attracts lots of fans, we have to expect some of this. Can the players complain? Not in good faith when they're raking in such large sums. I recall when winners of golf tournaments took in $25,000. Now it's frequently $2,000,000.

What an amazing victory for Team USA. The pressure to win was intense given the large lead squandered in 2014 at Gleneagles. The performance by Phil Mickelson cannot be understated - after speakng out unfavorably of Tom Watson (one of the greatest American golfers) Phil played great and combined for 19 birdies to halve his singles match with Sergio Garcia whose Ryder Cup record of recent years is likely second only to Ian Poulter who did not play. Bravo USA and to you Phil!

The US just announced they still don't plan to play in The Ryder Cup next year, offering as an excuse that the event is only played every two years.

Sounds like a cop-out to me.
Drunken, shrieking crowds do NOT enhance the sport of golf. Maybe they should stop serving alcohol at these events.
Don't blame it on Bubba.  Blame it on the Bro culture that excludes adult behavior.
odd comment. they're still part of Europe whether or not they're in the eu or not. there are other European countries not in the eu and they are still European.
I suppose you have forgotten about the European fan at the Belfry who threw a soda can at an American player?
that's one. how many 'fans' were escorted from the course this weekend? if you believe that americans are/were more civil than Europeans you should have your objectivity gene checked out....
I've been watching the ryder cup for years. maybe i'm an amnesiac, but I don't recall the Europeans ever being as boorish as the American fans....
The US team was favoured.

Perhaps one thing to consider is that if nearly everyone is quiet, then the one or two jerks (or even 10 or 20) can be heard clearly. In other sports the non-stop din blankets unsportseerson-like comments. Not an excuse but when you have that many rabid, nationalistic (say jingoistic if you like) fans in a hotly contested event, it happens. The players also did their part to keep the things hot…
That's golf entertainment for you. Pro golfers understand that, it is their breadbasket.
Well excuse poor Willett, he only won the Masters this year.
at least nobody took a knee during the playing of the National Anthem

Bart, root for your country...but give a thought, too, to basic sportsmanship, basic hospitality, basic respect for the opposition--some of the greatest golfers in the world.  The rowdy, rude, and jingoistic jerks were an embarrassment to fans everywhere who can support their own while still showing appreciation for great golf.  All in all, a demonstration by rubes that the United States is losing ground fast as a hone of sophisticated and knowledgable sporting fans.
It's the third in the last eleven matches, not years.

What is wrong with Millennials that they have to amp everything up to ridiculous levels in order to enjoy it? Are they compensating for fundamentally empty emotional cores masked by everything required to be "awesome!!!!"?

Maybe if they just sat back and relaxed for a moment they would appreciate the beauty of many things going on around them. I would rather golf go under than become something akin to WWF.

Oh boy, here goes the Millennial bashing. I actually didn't foresee this one from a golf article. Anyways, I was there on Friday and Saturday and the boorish, loutish behavior was on full display from ALL generations - mainly males from their teens to "men" in their 60's. I am a millennial and I found the behavior absolutely disgusting, from spitting (why so much spitting people?), loudly passing gas, yelling insane comments and at really bad times, constantly chanting "USA" and acting like frat boys gone wild, regardless of age. A lot of people were wearing hockey and football jerseys, which, with their bellies hanging out, just seemed weird at a golf event. Some fun competitive ribbing is fine, but I was shocked to see such loutish behavior on shameless display from young and old.

These are the types of crowds and matches golf needs. If they want to reach millennials, golf has to change. And this type of match is a good start.

Reminds me of the comment from coach Al McGuire of Marquette when he was doing color commentary with Dick Enberg on a college basketball game. As a Freshman player was lining up an important free throw with thousands of fans from the opposing team yelling at him and making gestures to distract him, McGuire observed how different the staid game of golf was when crowds were instructed to remain quiet and still during their shots.

I've thought about that since and I must admit that the Ryder Cup is about the only golf match I'm interested in. Al was right.
Really?  The USA team were totally invested in this.  Did you not know that they get no income from this? They actually do it for love of Country.
Three days of simply great theater. Loved the Sunday intensity and camaraderie of McIlroy and Reed.
That is what the Ryder Cup people want to happen. They encourage that.
